Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: U and Th decay series dating of seafloor hydrothermal deposits
Award.AbstractNarration: Seafloor hydrothermal deposits form on time-scales of minutes to thousands of years, are products of significant heat and mass transfer from the oceanic crust to the oceans, and form in conjunction with activity that supports significant life in the deep-sea. Understanding time-scales over which these deposits form and whether they form continuously or episodically can provide important information about (1) energy and mass transfer between the ocean and crust; (2) environments, speciation rates, larvae dispersal, energy, and nutrient sources for hydrothermal biological communities; and (3) relationships between hydrothermal structure, crustal structure, and heat transfer within the crust. Unfortunately, there are currently no dependable methods to confidently date seafloor hydrothermal deposits to help us constrain some of these major processes. The most promising method involves measuring the radioactive decay of isotopes in the 238U- and 232Th- decay chains. The half-lives of target isotopes (238U-234U-230Th-226Ra-210Pb-210Po; 232Th-228Ra-228Th) range from 138 days to 75 kyrs, and allow investigation of samples ranging from ~1 to 105 years. These time-scales are appropriate for geologically young seafloor hydrothermal deposits. In addition, application of these isotopes is uniquely suited for dating minerals formed in seafloor hydrothermal deposits because geochemical processes isolate specific parent-daughter pairs in the U- and Th- series that can be exploited for age information. The motivation for this research is based on scientific need for a reliable method for dating seafloor hydrothermal deposits and to test the assumptions required for realization of the full potential of the 238U- and 232Th- method. This research combines a solid understanding of hydrothermal processes with high-precision isotopic measurements to rigorously test the assumptions that are central to full development of the analytical method and interpretation of the results and their application to seafloor hydrothermal vent chimney deposits. Goals will be to define the utility and limitations of the method and, hopefully, enable reliable dating of hydrothermal vent deposits of unknown age. The data produced on samples of known age, together with measurements of additional samples of unknown age, will be used to investigate the time-scales of hydrothermal processes at three distinct locations. Samples selected for analysis are in-hand and from (1) the Trans-Atlantic Geotraverse hydrothermal system (i.e., TAG); (2) the PACMANUS hydrothermal field in the Manus Basin in the Pacific Ocean near New Guinea; and (3) the Eastern Lau Spreading Center/Valu Fa Ridge in the Lau Basin of the western Pacific. Broader impacts of the study include the development of new analytical techniques and age pairs for geological applications, implications for ore deposit formation, public outreach, and broad dissemination of results to K-12 teachers, students, and the general public. Support of a graduate student and support of an institution in an EPSCoR stated (Wyoming) are additional impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on better understanding the time-scales of seafloor hydrothermal deposit formation. Seafloor hydrothermal deposits form along seafloor spreading centers (at mid-ocean ridges or in back-arc basins) as hot vent fluids exit the seafloor and mix with cold seawater. The vent fluids have a very different chemistry than seawater, having formed from interactions between seawater (that percolated into newly formed ocean crust and was heated) and ocean crustal rocks that solidified from magma; they are metal-rich and sulfate (SO4)-poor compared to seawater, which is sulfate-rich and metal-poor.  Early stages of deposit formation include precipitation of anhydrite (calcium sulfate, CaSO4), with the calcium coming from both seawater and vent fluid, and the sulfate only from seawater. Once the initial very porous framework is formed, metal sulfide minerals (e.g., pyrite, FeS2; chalcopyrite, CuFeS2) precipitate along inner sides of the deposits and within interstices.  These deposits are loci for significant transfer of heat and mass from Earth to the ocean, and the outflow areas provide habitats for unusual organisms, providing energy sources that fuel the base of an important deep-sea food chain.  Deposit sizes range from  ~10 meters diameter and heights of a few meters to mounds that stand ~50 meters high and are a few hundreds of meters in diameter.  The larger deposits are analogs of some types of economically viable volcanic-associated massive sulfide deposits found on land.

 A major issue in determining time-scales of deposit formation is that currently there is no dependable method for confidently dating hydrothermal deposits.  This project focused on testing assumptions used in calculating ages using a method that considers measurements of the radioactive decay of isotopes in the 238U- and 232Th- decay chains.  This technique takes advantage of the very different half-lives of 238U-234U-230Th-226Ra-210Pb-210Po; 232Th-228Ra-228Th that range from 138 days to 75,000 years.  This range allows dating of samples in the age range of ~1 to 100,000 years. Assumptions of this method include a requirement that the dated minerals remain closed systems (i.e., there is no addition or loss of U and Th from mineral alteration as the deposit forms), and that no Th is incorporated into initial deposit minerals.  To test these and other assumptions required for use of the 238U- and 232Th- method, samples were selected from vent fields in the Lau and Manus back-arc basins, from the sediment-hosted Guaymas Basin in the Gulf of California, and from the Trans-Atlantic Geotraverse (TAG) hydrothermal area on the slow-spreading mid-Atlantic Ridge.  The samples analyzed included subsamples of anhydrite and pyrite of unknown age from the TAG area and from the Manus basin, subsamples of the chalcopyrite linings of two black smoker chimneys that were actively venting and recovered in 2004 from TAG and 2009 from the Lau Basin, and a suite of very young (2 to 15 days old at the time of recovery) anhydrite-dominated early-stage chimney walls that were all recovered in 2009 from either vent fields in the Lau back-arc basin or vents in Guaymas Basin. This range of samples allowed testing of assumptions, and definition of limitations of the method, by combining high precision isotopic measurements with our understanding of hydrothermal processes. In particular, the focus was on very early stages of deposit formation, which allowed comparison of calculated ages with known ages for several samples. 

Broader implications of this study include that provision of age constraints would allow investigation of a range of topics including 1) the constancy or episodicity of mass and heat flux through seafloor hydrothermal systems; 2) the growth rates of deposits and how that may relate to geologic setting (including spreading rate, active volcanism, tectonic activity); and 3) possible effects of episodicity and/or growth rates on deep-sea biological communities. This project helped support the training of a University of Wyoming PhD student. Results of this project include a peer-reviewed paper, and several presentations about seafloor hydrothermal systems were given to retirees, teachers, undergraduates, and junior and senior high school students.
